awd_titl_txt: Preparing Professionals for Cybersecurity in the Government: Scholarships for Service
awd_abstract_narration:
The new CyberCorps®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program offered by Marymount University in Arlington, VA educates undergraduate and graduate students in cybersecurity, preparing them for critical positions in the Federal Government. Students are taught and mentored by full-time faculty, with a research focus, and part-time faculty who are working professionals, including SFS alumni. The program focuses on inquiry-learning with students playing an active role in developing cybersecurity techniques in the lab and in performing cybersecurity service-learning initiatives for local non-profit groups. Marymount, with its proven record of recruiting and educating students from underrepresented populations, launches students in cybersecurity careers in the Federal Government.  The inquiry-based approach to learning strengthens analytical and critical thinking skills that are vital to professionals working in the Federal Government cybersecurity field. By focusing on specific non-traditional populations like veterans, minorities and women, and community college students, Marymount will contribute to broadening the pool of cybersecurity professionals in the federal workforce.  Additionally, Marymount faculty and students, drawing on long established bonds with local high schools, will expose younger students to the opportunities for future careers in cybersecurity.

This SFS project involves the participation of Northern Virginia Community College.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of Marymount UNiversity's CyberCorps Scholarship for Servicec (SFS) project was to recruit, educate, and place a set of high-performing students in the government service as cybersecurity professionals, recognizing the documented continuing shortage in that field to protect our national security.  The additional goal was to increase the diversity of the cybersecurity workplace by encouraging applications from females, underrepresented minorities, students with disabilities, and veterans and by encouraging applications from students who have taken a more untraditional route to their education including completing studies at a community college. While in the program, students were given scholarships (tuition and stipends) to study full-time for two or three years and they were expected to contribute to the cybersecurity knowledge at the university and in the community. As a result of receiving their scholarship, on graduation, the students were required to work in a government cybersecurity position for the same amount of time that they received funding.

Over the project we achieved these goals directly and indirectly. 21 students received the full scholarship for 2 or 3 years to study at the undergraduate or master’s levels and graduated with high GPAs. Of these, 10 were female, 14 were minorities, 3 were veterans, and 2 were disabled, so meeting our proposed broadening participation goals.  61% of the students studied at community college before coming to Marymount, thus we were able to give these students, mostly minorities, the opportunity to get a four-year degree and to enter a well-paid career. Our graduates from the program are working across the government in intelligence, civilian agencies, the defense organizations, and the national labs, most staying long after their required commitment under the scholarship.

In addition to their studies, these students were very active in university clubs and activities and influenced other students to enter cybersecurity as a career. For example, they participated in our first NSF/NSA GenCyber camp, designed to promote careers in cybersecurity at the high school level. In addition, the students participated in a range of research activities, and several presented at conferences and published papers. Two of our alums have earned doctoral degrees since graduating from the program, and in addition to working for the government, they are also teaching cybersecurity courses at community colleges and universities, further helping educate more students for the cybersecurity profession.

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2022
Modified by: Diane Murphy
